s.text: Sixteen (16) conference papers were written by legal services leaders across the country on topics that enhanced and enlightened the conference discussions.
service delivery models; and ?? Other services such as mediation and alternative dispute resolution work.
service delivery models; and ?? Other services such as mediation and alternative dispute resolution work.
Conference participants reflected a true cross section of the country, with clients and advocates attending from more than twenty-eight (28) states.

Building State Justice Communities: A State Planning Report from the Legal Services Corporation, issued in March 2001, highlights the state planning successes of 18 states in developing coordinated plans to increase resources and services to clients statewide.

In April 2001, just beyond the reporting period, LSC held a three-day conference in Hershey, Pennsylvania, entitled "Creating Client-Centered State Communities of Justice".
The project attempts to identify the number of people served by the following types of work, and obtain descriptions of programs' efforts and of successes.
As part of this project, LSC solicited public comment via notices published in the Federal Register and on the LSC Website in November 2000.

The technology used to capture and evaluate information in response to the RFP permits LSC to compile and assess key information about the delivery system at the program, state, regional, and national level.
The Corporation continued to demonstrate its ability to ensure both compliance with program rules and regulations, and the maintenance of high quality legal assistance to eligible clients.
how to design and implement a comprehensive system of high quality legal services;

LSC's Board recognizes the value of the Inspector General function and remains committed to working with the OIG to achieve our goal of providing high quality legal assistance to the poor of our nation.

The RFP was also modified to obtain more comprehensive information on sub-grantees that receive twenty-five percent (25%) or more of the LSC grant award, and sub-grantees that deliver a full range of services to a specific geographic area within the applicant's service area.
In April 2001, just beyond the reporting period, LSC held a three-day conference in Hershey, Pennsylvania, entitled "Creating Client-Centered State Communities of Justice".

Dates for three additional visits will be selected in the near future.
The Board appoints LSC's President, who serves as the Corporation's chief executive officer, subject to general policies established by the Board.

I am pleased to transmit the comments of the Legal Services Corporation ("LSC" or "Corporation") Board of Directors ("Board") regarding the Semiannual Report of LSC's Office of Inspector General ("OIG") for the six-month period of October 1, 2000 through March 31, 2001.
LEGAL SERVICES CORPORATION BOARD OF DIRECTORS
The Board appoints LSC's President, who serves as the Corporation's chief executive officer, subject to general policies established by the Board.

The conference was attended by a diverse group of more than seventy (70) individuals, comprised of clients and client advocates, members of the bench and the academic community, LSC board members and staff, and national partners.
The review effort is still underway and a final report is expected to be presented to the LSC Board for consideration in June 2001.

I am pleased to transmit the comments of the Legal Services Corporation ("LSC" or "Corporation") Board of Directors ("Board") regarding the Semiannual Report of LSC's Office of Inspector General ("OIG") for the six-month period of October 1, 2000 through March 31, 2001.

I am pleased to transmit the comments of the Legal Services Corporation ("LSC" or "Corporation") Board of Directors ("Board") regarding the Semiannual Report of LSC's Office of Inspector General ("OIG") for the six-month period of October 1, 2000 through March 31, 2001.
The Inspector General is appointed by, reports to and serves under the general supervision of LSC's Board of Directors.

Adopted by the Board of Directors on January 28, 2000, the Plan commits LSC to dramatically enhance the impact of legal services programs throughout the nation by improving access to legal services while enhancing their quality.
